column1: Protvino (Russian: Протвино́) is a town in Moscow Oblast
column3: located about 100 kilometers (62 mi) south of Moscow and 15 kilometers (9.3 mi) west of Serpukhov
column4: on the left bank of the Protva River. Population: 37

column1: Construction of an urban-type settlement intended to house a large high energy physics research laboratory started in 1958
column2: and the Rosatom Institute for High Energy Physics was opened here in 1965. The institute is known for the 70 GeV proton accelerator which was the largest in the world at the time it was launched in 1967
column3: and other physics research. Town status was granted in 1989. The UNK Collider was the last big planned particle accelerator.

column1: Among the discoveries made at IHEP are that of antihelium and the Serpukhov cross-section effect.
Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: it is incorporated as Protvino Town Under Oblast Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column3: Protvino Town Under Oblast Jurisdiction is incorporated as Protvino Urban Okrug.

column1: In the city the Protvino railroad station is located
column2: although it is only used for cargo transport. Public transport is provided by buses.
